@toadovision It’s down to the landlord to do it, as it’s rented, and they’ve no incentive to do so as they don’t benefit from the expense of it.

@gordonrlove It’s ultimately down to the landlord, and they have no incentive to make properties energy efficient coz it’s expensive for them and it’s the tenant that benefits from the lower bills. It’s hopefully going to be addressed in rental reforms, but how many more will die before then?
@rohbo1 They’ve been openly waging that war since 2010.
@mojomoomoo I’m on variable rate at the moment, and that’s all that they’re offering me now.

@gordonrlove I lay in bed and a literal breeze comes through the roof, through the slat doors of the wardrobes fitted into the eaves, and it’s honestly like sleeping in a tent. Short of a rebuild and landlord sorting out insulation, everything else is like putting a bandaid on a broken neck.

@gordonrlove We’ve done everything. Bubble wrap over the doors, thermal curtains on EVERYTHING, multiple draught excluders, insulating draught foam in gaps, it’s rented, I’m limited but really have tried EVERYTHING. And am lucky I could outlay for all that stuff last year, or it’d be worse.

I’m just venting, I’ve survived everything else so far, I don’t want anything - I can sell my photography, pitch for writing commissions (in what spare time, but I’ll make some), I have options - insecure and exhausting but I know I’m lucky to have them. I’m just…so very tired.

I’m by no means the worst off, but I’m not doing great. Stuck in a cold draughty massive house that I signed up to as a two income household and am stuck in alone now footing all the ludicrous bills, on an authors 7%-on-sale-price twice yearly royalty cheques and freelance work.

These are the only two options being offered to me. A 224% price increase, an extra £433 a month. How can this be right?! I can’t move, I can’t unplug anything else, I barely use my heating, we don’t have a telly plugged in or a router etc, don’t use a tumble dryer, WHAT THE FUCK https://t.co/U4DJ93Tk5u

I finally looked at my energy account. My direct debit is £200 a month (I am ludicrously frugal about it, but it’s an old, draughty bungalow with the bedrooms in the uninsulated eaves, and I have arthritis, SB and I both have respiratory difficulties, all made worse by the cold.)

Please stop bloody voting for them, they REALLY don’t care about you. And they certainly won’t be doing any of these things, because YOU are paying their energy bills on ALL of their homes, while being unable to afford your own and preparing for a life of cold, miserable penury.

If you’ve answered yes to any one of these questions, then congratulations, you’ve won the dubious prize of being royally mucked over by this Governments failure to mitigate the energy price caps and act in your best interests in the cost of living crisis.
🥘 Using, or considering switching to, a slow cooker to use less energy when cooking meals.
⚡️ Putting a single electric blanket on the couch/armchair/bed in the daytime, and covering it with a blanket, to limit the amount of time you need to turn the heating on.

🧶 Wearing a jumper, or coat, or thermals, or multiple thin layers, or a hat, or gloves, or a scarf, inside the house. In fact, having very little noticeable difference between your ‘indoor clothes’ and ‘outdoor clothes’.
🏡 Confining yourself to one room to conserve heat and energy.

☀️ Looking at the weather for the days ahead to identify the days/times where you might really really need to put the heating on, and picking out periods where you think you might get away with leaving it off for long stretches of time.
🔥 Picking radiators or heaters to turn off from rooms you’re only in briefly, like hallways, bathrooms, spare bedrooms, kitchens, etc.
💡 Picking light bulbs you think you could lose from ‘unnecessary’ places, like hallways, porches, bathrooms, outdoor lights, spare bedrooms, bedrooms, wherever.

I’ve been very poor, and I’ve been just-about-holding-it-together, and I’ve really been no better than that at any point in my life, but if everything goes tits up again at least I can be sad in my warm hat and coat and scarf, clutching my satchel, looking absolutely banging.

And a decade of PTSD, a panic attack whenever someone knocks on my front door, obsessive, compulsive, hoarding, monstrously weird behaviours around STUFF and money, years of therapy, so many meds I rattle, and an unending, gnawing feeling of guilt whenever I Have A Nice Thing.

So over the years, in between the painstaking frugality and £20 food shops, I’ve amassed a decent satchel (AGCJ), a classic trench coat (AYI120R), a decent pair of boots, some butter soft leather leggings, some nice furniture, a good dining table, and a Stetson hat.

I have a deal with myself that when I hand every book in, I buy myself one ridiculous, luxurious thing with the delivery payment. It’s partly an insurance policy (if life tits up again, I have some saleable things), but mostly as a ‘hell yeah I bought this with my WORDS’.

Trolls in my mentions carping about the audacity of me treating myself to a hat: if you switched to the 30p canned tomatoes and 29p pasta for [checks notes] a whole damn decade, you too could possibly afford to spend the change on a small Stetson.

One day, ONE DAY, SB and I will have our forever home (I have a plan!) and one day I’ll have my own roses, my own apple tree, my own orangery, my own front door I can paint whatever damn colour I please and thrice a year as the mood takes me. But not today. And that’s okay.

I’ve looked, I can’t afford it. But I’m sure as hell going to be first on the new neighbours doorsteps with a casserole welcoming them to the street. Just for a fleeting moment of standing in the orangery and living in a makebelieve world where it could have been mine. 🥰

There’s a house near me that I have walked past every day for three years dreaming about. It has original old lead glass windows, an archway of roses, very healthy apple tree, an orangery for my food photography, it’s wild and old and rickety and beautiful and now it’s for sale.

@Repealist_ And for the ‘exposure’ line, I tend to point out that THEY approached ME, so my exposure balance seems pretty healthy, otherwise how would they have found me? Can’t pay the bills with applause and Twitter likes, go get your cold hard cash - you deserve it! ❤️
@Repealist_ (Again, this doesn’t always work, but if you don’t ask you don’t get. And normalising fair and assertive remuneration only raises up everyone who does this kind of work.)

@Repealist_ AND (sorry!) if they want to record it+put it online, that should also be recompensed accordingly, because a) that’s hella stressful and b) they get two different services from you; the in person talk and the content in perpetuity. Even if it’s an extra £50, own your boundaries!

@Repealist_ And always keep in mind that they’re not paying you for a ten minute talk, they’re paying you for all the years of expertise and hard work that have got you to the podium in the first place. Anything else I can help with, bung me a DM. X

@Repealist_ And there’s no obligation to do freebies for charities btw, that’s just a personal thing I do for my faves. Again, everyone else involved in that event will be being paid for their participation, so if you’re comfortable with it, it’s totally fine for you to be paid too!
@Repealist_ AND if they say ‘we can only cover expenses’ then say ‘cool my travel expenses will be X and my time and presence and expertise expenses will be Y, thankyou very much’. 😏

@Repealist_ And finally, if the number doesn’t make you feel slightly embarrassed at your absolute chutzpah for even typing it, it’s too low a starting point for negotiations. And always keep in mind that that noted orator Theresa May got £40k to talk to a pension fund company for 10 minutes

@Repealist_ PS I’ve never actually got 10% of ticket prices but I still ask - it gives a figure for them to bat down. And don’t forget travel expenses in advance - you shouldn’t be out of pocket for it. (Again I always forget to do this, so telling you is a good reminder for me to do it!)

@Repealist_ And don’t underestimate the recovery time - the adrenaline crash, relief, and probable exhaustion from sitting up all night fretting the night before wipes me right out. If it’s a day, I take the afternoon off. If it’s an evening one, take the next morning off or do light duties!

@Repealist_ It’s taken me ten years to learn this. And a Zoom gig is no less ‘real’ than a conference hall, you still need to do all the same prep etc, so don’t undersell yourself just because you can secretly wear pyjama pants for it 😏

@Repealist_ And always ask for double what you’d actually do it for, because they will always always knock you down. And don’t ask what their budget is, say ‘my rates for this would be X but I’d be willing to negotiate around this’. You set the parameters, THEY approached you for a reason.

@Repealist_ And if it’s a ticketed gig or paid work conference and they say they don’t have a speaker budget, go back with ‘so you want to put my name on the flyer to sell this but I’ll be the only person in the room not getting paid to be there? Interesting 🧐’

@Repealist_ Set yourself a sliding scale - I do:
Long term charity partners: free
Corporate gigs: not free
Ticketed: 7-10% of ticket price x audience
Banks/financial institutions: literally have all the money, ask for it
Remember to factor in calls, prep, rehearsal time, travel, recovery x

@gutterbookshop Soaked overnight, these only need 20 minutes. And you can pop a lid on after that and trap all the heat in the pan, turn the hob off, and leave it for another 30-60 minutes to continue to cook in the residual heat without costing another penny.

And if you’re looking to get some more protein and fibre in your diet, wherever you’d normally serve rice, cook half your usual quantity of rice per person, along with 20g of mung beans (soaked overnight or for 6 hours) in the same pan, for a simple side dish to go with anything.

They’re also excellent in a sausage casserole, so you can use half the amount of sausages, sliced thinly so they go further, and still have a fair whack of protein in it. And lots of other good stuff too.

@Ricky19681968 If they’re soaked overnight they only need about 20 minutes of cooking, with no salt added until the end of the process as otherwise they seize and harden, but yes as with all beans they should be cooked until you can squish one between finger and thumb.

I’m also trying a thing where I put soaked beans in a Thermos (or other heat retaining vacuum flask) with boiling water to see if it’s possible to cook them without using a load of gas or electric. I suspect some will be more successful than others, but I’ll keep you posted! 🔥

When I was a single mum on benefits I was bloody terrified of dried beans+pulses - didn’t want to take the risk cooking something unknown because there wasn’t the money to waste if it turned out badly. So I’m going to try to demystify them a bit and hope that helps other people!

Use in soup, stew, daal, curry, warm salads, bolognese, as a side dish, anything with mince to bulk it out. They hold their shape, can stand a little or a lot of cooking, and have a mild, slightly sweet flavour that can take hefty flavours or stand alone with a lemony dressing.

They’re £1.50 for 500g from the ‘world foods’ aisle at Asda (and other supermarkets, I’m not sponsored by the green one it’s just in walking distance for me!) which works out at 9p per 30g portion (which increases to about 75g when cooked).

They may be tiny but they’re a powerhouse of goodness - high in protein, fibre, folate, manganese, magnesium, and a good source of vitamin B1, iron, copper, potassium, zinc, vitamins B2, B3, B6, B5 and selenium - all good stuff!

Anyway I’m up at 4am for a radio show, so I should really go to bed and stop worrying about The Internet. No, a sheet of A4 paper isn’t going to solve food poverty. But it might help a few people save a few quid and feel a bit less shit, and that’s got to mean something.

I’m getting some horrible comments, and it’s making me a bit sad and fretful. I’ve written about this method in a few of my books and shared it many times before; and things are going to get tougher for a lot of us in the coming months so I thought I’d try to help in a small way.
@JBav81 Oh I know!

I hope it doesn’t come across as hectoring or condescending; it’s just a comfort blanket I use to keep the gremlins away really, and thought I’d share in case it’s useful to anyone else. I try my best to be helpful and not patronising, and that’s all I was hoping to achieve here.

I was very nervous about posting this because I don’t want people to misconstrue it - when I was in my worst places I couldn’t have done this, and I’m not suggesting it’s a solution to food poverty - I’d hope my last decade of work on this would stand me in good stead here.

But for the majority of people looking to save a bit of money on their food shop, give it a go. It’s quite laborious the first time you do it, but as someone who has lived in food poverty, I find it quite powerfully reassuring to have a physical list of all of the food I have. 🥰

Anyway I hope this is useful to someone; it won’t be for everyone, and I am aware that ‘check what you have in’ is bloody useless advice for those who have absolutely nothing in the cupboards - I know, I’ve been there, it sucks, and i’m sorry.

It’s genuinely revolutionised the way I cook and shop and reduces a lot of my anxiety around food, impulse purchasing things I don’t need, reduces food waste, and keeps the food bill low. It also helps me plan balanced meals, and sparks off all kinds of avenues of creativity.

So breakfast is a homemade berry bircher.

Lunch tends to be tinned fish on toast, and veg crudités (any combo of radish, carrots, cucumber, celery, cherry tomatoes) with a home made yoghurt dip.

Dinner is some kind of beans and veg with fish or chicken.

All very little effort!

In the evening I get two fish fillets out of the freezer and pop them in the fridge to defrost. Then I weigh 120g of dried beans and cover them with cold water to soak. Lastly, I put 100g frozen berries, 100g yoghurt and 50g porridge oats in a bowl in the fridge for the morning.

At the moment I’ve got a lot of frozen fish, frozen chicken, dried beans and pulses kicking about, so I’ll be using a lot of those over the next few weeks. It means being a bit organised, which doesn’t come naturally to me, so I’m trying to get into a routine and so far, so good!

It also means that my shopping list for the week is made up of ‘gap filling’ - so if i’m running low on fruit and veg, I’ll prioritise that. If i’m short on wholegrains, I’ll pick up some brown rice. Etc etc.
Starting with protein first, and trying to pick one thing from each column, helps visualise and create balanced meals.
I then highlight things that need using imminently, so fruit on the turn, fresh produce nearing its use by date, etc, and plan meals around them, adding in bits from the other columns.

Then I go through the fridge, freezer and cupboard and note down every single thing I have in. When I’m feeling extra meticulous I weigh it all, but usually I do an estimate of number of units or portions.
I get an A4 sheet of lined paper and divide it into 4 vertical columns: PROTEINS, CARBOHYDRATES, FRUIT & VEG, and the end column is split into two, FLAVOURS and SNACKS.
One of my best tips for keeping the food shop down to £20 a week is to do a full stocktake every now and then of what’s in the cupboard, fridge and freezer. Let me explain how it works.

Now I really need to put my shopping away, and continue to work on the VBI, but first I’m going to just take a moment to sit and be thankful that out there in this crushing capitalist circus, there are some good people, with the power to do great, simple things, doing just that.

To Megan at head office especially, but to all of the in-store grocery colleagues who will have had to do a zillion bay and SEL changes very quickly too, I’ve done that job, it’s an absolute menace. Sorry about that! 😬
So I guess I just wanted to say thanks to everyone at Asda who has worked really hard over the last few weeks to bring the missing SmartPrice products back.
And today I cried, quietly, to myself, in Asda, as the enormity of all of the last few weeks finally sank in amongst all the white labels in my shopping basket.

I’ve cried tears of humiliation when a shelf edge label turned out to be advertising an expired promotion, tipping my shopping over what I could afford from the six pounds or so in change - the only money I had in the world - in my hand.

I’ve cried in supermarkets plenty in the last 10 years. Putting back jam that had crept up by sixpence, meaning SB and I faced a week of bone dry toast. Trying to work out what to put back, what to do without, out of a tenners worth of groceries that weren’t enough to start with.

And today, I could put extra treats in my shopping basket for SB. Today, I managed to get so much in my £20 basket that I was clutching rice and oats and muesli to my bosom as I wrestled to the checkout. Today is the happiest shopping experience in over a decade.

I don’t live in poverty any longer (I’m not well off either, but that’s not the point). I still add up my shopping with a pen + paper as I walk round the supermarket, and I do still hold my breath when I tap my bank card on the reader, waiting for it to go through. Many of us do.
(The rest write great blousy emails, but I can’t eat those nor pop them in the foodbank trolley, so…)

The impact that this will have on millions of people, is impossible to overstate. And of all of the supermarkets that reached out to me in the last weeks, Asda have been the only ones to actually act on our conversations and make things right.
The turnaround for this has been almost immediate - the speed at which they responded, not just with words, but with exactly what they said they would do - has been absolutely remarkable.

I was very quick to vilify Asda for what I saw as a change of direction for their company, and a watering down of their commitment to an entire group of their customers. And to their credit, they read it all, and a LOT of your comments too, reached out, and said they’d do better.

Right. Tea. Before I say something in frustration and fury that I might come to regret. Keep Twitter warm for me, I’ll be back in a bit.

Newsflash: rich people can’t be trusted to make good choices. You’ve only got to look at the expense claims of some MPs, or the eye watering prevalence of drugs in Parliament, or the sheer audacity of PartyGate. Oh, don’t like all being tarred with the same brush? Well then.

The nanny state implications of doling out approved, specified, ‘healthy’ foods comes with the murky and ill-concealed implication that ‘poor people can’t be trusted to make good choices’. It’s so tightly woven into the mindsets of those who think they can make decisions for us.

- Give people enough money to live on
- Voucher/hamper schemes tend to focus on profit for the organisation not on actually fulfilling a need
- Foodbank use increasing rapidly
- Stop sanctioning people and pushing them into poverty
- Let people make their own day to day choices

They ignore their own commissioned experts advice and findings, because they don’t tend to like what they have to say. Which has been, overwhelmingly, from literally thousands of experts over the last ten years, almost identical again and again and again.

Of course, I don’t expect anything to change as a result of this thread. This Government have commissioned endless reports on hunger and poverty: I’ve been involved in the Feeding Britain inquiry, the parliamentary foodbank debate, the School Food Plan, the National Food Strategy

11. I could write another 90 reasons as to why this is an utterly terrible, clumsy, downright daft idea, but I’m going to go and have a cup of tea and a walk around the garden for a bit, because I’m trying very hard not to swear on Twitter right now and my head is full of curses.

(And they will drop, because people will be getting their emergency food from the chemist and not the church, remember), it’ll be whisked away again. Leaving everyone as hungry as they were before, but with no support system left in place. See the £20 UC uplift for previous form.

10. This is the same Government that took away prescriptions for gluten free essentials for coeliacs - so even if this is rolled out sensitively, nobody’s pocketing wads of cash, everything’s legit, it’ll be temporary. Mark my words, once those pesky foodbank numbers drop (contd)

9. Cash first. All, and I mean ALL of the numerous decent and experienced peer support networks, charities and organisations working with people at the bitterly sharp end advocate a ‘cash first’ support system. It’s about dignity, agency, choice, humanity, trust and decency.

(They rely on people not being nerdy or bothered enough to look at that stuff, and in a world of soft soap client journalism, they’ve got away with being complacent about it for a long time. Cronyism, meet an autistic campaigner with an eye for detail and dogged pursuit of truth)

8. Back to ‘who benefits’. A moment to remind you that LOTS of Conservative MPs hold shares in private healthcare companies. There’s a list somewhere from a few years ago, but I’ll be scrutinising the audit trail on this against the register of members interests at some point.

…When in reality they’re just getting their emergency food parcel from the chemist, not the church. I have to hand it to them, that could have been quite clever, if it weren’t so transparent. Hungry people are still hungry people, doesn’t matter who’s feeding them.

7. The cynic in me thinks that this is a ploy to massage the foodbank figures, by moving people from the foodbank queue to the doctors surgery. With a profit margin somewhere to boot. Give it a year and they’ll be able to say that foodbank figures have dropped… (cont’d)

6. Lack of agency. It’s shitty enough being poor without having to beg your doctor for apples. It’s a world of no. No you can’t go to the funfair, no we can’t afford new shoes, no we can’t put the heating on, no there’s nothing for supper. Let. People. Make. Their. Own. Choices.

5. Who benefits? Call me naive, but I’d like to follow the money trail on this one. Which companies will be awarded the lucrative contracts for these ‘healthy food’ vouchers or hampers. For example, the largest similar scheme in the UK is Chartwells. We all know how that went.

4. GPs are already overworked, underfunded, overstretched, their shrinking resource pool absolutely decimated by twelve years of Conservative led austerity cuts and brutal cuts to the NHS. Making them into ad hoc social workers on top isn’t going to help.

3. So how are GPs going to prescribe this ‘healthy food’ to people whose circumstances they are largely entirely unaware of? It relies on the recipient instigating that contact, which, from personal and well evidenced experience, those at risk of hunger don’t tend to do. See #2.

2. Evidence from foodbanks own referral data shows that people who need their services are often not engaging with local health and social services, for many reasons. Lack of money for transport, poor mental health, stigma, (misplaced but still very real) shame, isolation, etc.

1. ‘Healthy food’ isn’t really the issue here. It’s poverty. And putting a handful of ‘healthy foods’ under a £9.25 prescription charge? You can get a considerable amount of healthy food for that anyway. Even with the price rises. That’s not the point.

On the face of it, you might think that this is a good thing. If I didn’t know this Government, I might even charitably think it’s a well intentioned idea, poorly communicated and executed. It’s not. There’s so much wrong with it, I don’t even know where to start. But I’ll try. https://t.co/qBE7y61aCC

It was a box of a dozen ten minutes of simple bliss, escapes from the monotony of feeling I had no value whatsoever. So yes, donate cereal and pasta and canned fish and period products as they’re essentials. But also, if you can, donate a small treat. You’ll make someone’s day.
The notion that a complete stranger thought that I (also a complete stranger) deserved a treat, something to make my dark days just a tiny bit better, wasn’t just a box of biscuits.

When I was a food bank user, some years ago now, I remember receiving a box of M&S shortbreads in amongst all the white-labelled basics, and the feeling of absolute gratitude I had for something so simple and luxurious in my bland and miserable world will never leave me.

In case you missed it on BBC Radio Sheffield just now, I just did an impassioned plea for donating not just the value and basic range goods to food banks, but also consider popping in the best biscuits you can afford to give.

In the absence of a CEO and a direction, my suspicions from 10 days ago appear to be being borne out: Asda have taken their eye off the ‘value and values driven’ ethic that once underpinned their pricing points, and are instead chasing the M&S convenience market.

Asda plan to open another 200 ‘Asda On The Move’ forecourt stores in the next year, but the catch is that they will stock the premium ranges of products, not the value ranges. So yes, Asda products will be more widely available, but only the very profitable higher end ones.

Asda have already opened a few of their new high-end, premium range focused, forecourt convenience stores, stocking primarily products from the Extra Special range. The black and white branding and overall layout seems to be a clear shot across the bows of M&S To Go.
The Issa brothers, Moshin and Zuber, who took over in 2020, made their fortune on petrol forecourt convenience stores. This becomes relevant.

Their CEO, Roger Burnley, estimated salary £4million, announced his intention to resign last March. There is no current CEO in place, so the organisation is rudderless, flailing in a crowding market with no figurehead leadership or direction.

I’ve been doing some research into Asda to try to work out what they’re playing at, and I’ve come across some interesting information. (A lot of it from their own corporate press releases, on their own website.)

Investment in early education, warm safe decent homes, full bellies is proven to pay back dividends in fiscal savings on healthcare, social care, justice, social support, and later down the line. I’ve been making the emotional argument for a decade now. Time for the economic one.

This isn’t about the cost of a bag of rice. This is about the disproportionate impact that 12 years of austerity ideology has had on those who can least afford to shoulder the burden. Its time to find some of the magic money used to bail out large corporations and use it properly

This is just the beginning. @jrf_uk @TrussellTrust @CAP_UK @ONS @dwppressoffice @UKLabour @unitetheunion @HenryDimbleby @mrjamesob @guardian @thesundaypeople & more - get some good sleep over the next week or so, because once those numbers are in, we have serious work to do. 👊📢

the #VimesBootsIndex and the new ONS to lobby, with hard data and facts, for a guaranteed decent income for EVERYONE, irregardless of employment status, household, or physical ability. Real Living Wages, Universal Basic Income, and benefits in line with the TRUE cost of living.

The knock-on impact of the change to the way the ONS will collect and report food prices has the potential to kickstart an avalanche of change: the Govt may not listen to a lefty loudmouth but they can’t not listen to their official organisations. The next goal is to use both >

6. Your data and info will not be stored.

3. If you have physical receipts, you can scan or clearly photograph them and send them over too.

4. If you have kept a record of your shopping prices in another way, eg a spreadsheet, and you want to share this, we would be very grateful!

5. Your data and info will not be sold

1. We need shopping receipts from the Big Four supermarkets: Asda, Morrison’s, Sainsbury’s, Tesco, from 2012-2022.

2. They will be printed for filing in evidence folders, with ALL identifying info (name, address, etc) removed, and the original emails will be deleted.

CALL FOR EVIDENCE. In order to compile the #VimesBootsIndex, we need more data than my own collection of shopping receipts holds. If you want to help, please forward (removing your identifying info) any online shopping receipts to vimesbootsindex@gmail.com. See below for more!

But I have this platform and every now and then I get an opportunity to use it for good. What kind of prick would I be if I, no longer in poverty, stopped campaigning about it? So I’ll continue, and if it makes you uncomfortable, good. It’s meant to.

Whenever I write about poverty, some people always crop up to say that I am making a career out of austerity. Darlings, I would much rather write a £30 travelogue cookbook fannying barefoot around the Northern Cypriot mountains of my ancestors. Austerity fucking sucks.

The last line in my daily prayer is this: ‘Just for today I will be unafraid…And believe that as I give to the world, so the world will give to me’.

I don’t always get things right, and my principles do prove expensive at times, but I do my best to be guided by them, and God.🙏🏼

I’m hoping to update it monthly across a range of supermarkets as a fairer reflection on how inflation impacts those at the sharp end of the scale. And I’ve been offered help from a bunch of experts, including ex ONS staff and retail buyers.

It’s essentially a shopping basket of basic goods at the very basic and budget end of the scale - I’ve got enough historical data from my own receipts and the granular mathematics recorded in my own recipes over the last ten years.

I’m working on something at the moment that is going to take the weekend to pull together, but it’s provisionally titled the VBPI: The Vimes Boots Price Index. It’s named after Sir Terry Pratchetts Vimes Boots Theory Of Economics. It’s a big complicated job, and I’m on it. 🙏🏼

I’m also recreating two of my other original £10 food shops this weekend for pieces I’m writing for newspapers that featured them at the time. They were from another supermarket because I lived closer to it then - this cost of living issue isn’t going away and neither am I.

I’m walking home (25 mins empty handed) with a camping rucksack and a wheeley trolley (40 minutes at slower pace with two brief rests), and then I have to make dinner for me and my son, so don’t hold your breath for the update!

So when I get home, I’ll post the original and then post what I managed to get with the same money, and see if you’d have balanced the book any better. In five minutes flat, with two heavy baskets, having to keep all the prices in your head, and an irritable child in tow.

Now I’m lucky enough that I have food in my cupboards, this is a demonstration of how prices on a very specific basket of goods has changed over a fixed period of time, not me pleading poverty. But I’m not far enough away from my own experiences to not be affected by this.

And now I’m standing in the supermarket, using my phone as a calculator, trying to work out on the spot what several items to put back that will still be roughly nutritionally balanced for the week but come in under the £20.

I’m done being polite now. Done with rules of averages that don’t take into account millions of peoples horrible, traumatising, hungry days and nights and days on end. My DMs are full of people who are still tormented by their own experiences. Just sit down and LISTEN to us.

Yes I’ve written about so much of this over the last ten years, but there’s so much of it I haven’t written about too. I’m lucky enough to have food in my cupboard now, but I STILL hold my breath when I put my PIN in to pay for it. I STILL shop with a calculator and a notepad.

Checking your bank balance before walking into the supermarket. Taking your last tenner out in cash before a bill grabs it meaning you won’t be able to eat that week. Asking the foodbank staff to put six sugars in your tea because that’s all the calories you’ll have that day.

Sitting opposite a child who is pushing their meagre dinner around hoping they leave enough for you to mop up with a piece of bread after they finish so your stomach just stops HURTING. Stealing a half eaten Big Mac out of a bin. God how many times do I have to relive this shit

If you’ve never used a sock as a sanitary towel, or the free newspaper from outside the train station, if you’ve never cried at a checkout because the 6p price rise on a jar of jam meant you and your kid were having dry toast all week, sit down and listen to those of who have.

(These are specific examples, and both things that I did more than once, but by no means are they the only examples of the lengths that desperately hungry people will go to in order to fool themselves for just one moment that they aren’t desperately hungry)

If you’ve never nibbled a stock cube to try to ease hunger pains, or drunk the formula milk that the foodbank gave your baby, you really have no business trying to tell people who have experienced real poverty that we ‘just don’t understand economics’. Oh, we really fucking do.

If anyone else is curious about my workings:

45p/1000g = 0.045p/1g rice at 2021 price.

£1/500g = 0.2p/1g rice at 2022 price.

0.2 - 0.045 to find the difference = 0.155p/1g

0.155 (difference) / 0.045 (original) = 3.44

3.44 * 100 to get the percentage increase = 344%

Thanks everyone who has amplified this thread. I’ve been tracking these price rises forensically for a decade and it’s nice to know I kept all the (literal) receipts for something. Not sure what the answer is, but collectively refusing to be gaslit by the Government is a start.

I mean of all the things, the Prime Minister claiming that he’s cutting the cost of living while the price of basic food products shoot up by THREE HUNDRED AND FORTY FOUR PERCENT is the one I’m properly angry enough to riot over.

@nigel_callaghan They just offset it by raising the prices of other products - they’re probably what’s known as ‘loss leaders’ - ie the strong brand association that gets people through the door in the first place, where they’ll then spend more than that £10 because they’re there.

Now, picture if you will, the demographic of the voter who has kept the current Party in power for the last 11 years. Imagine the Chancellor having to explain to them that their precious microwave dinner now cost almost four times what it did yesterday.

Yeah, didn’t think so.

To return to the luxury ready meal example, if the price of that had risen at the same rate as the cheapest rice in the supermarket, that £7.50 lasagne would now cost £25.80.

Dine In For £10 would be £34.40.

We’re either all in this together, or we aren’t.

(Spoiler: we aren’t)
@DorothyKoomson Thanks D x

@george_salmon @Jan__G I worked for a supermarket in my youth and every morning some poor sod would have the job of printing the new SELs (shelf edge labels) and traipsing round the entire store subtly changing the prices of hundreds of products. Every. Single. Day. I don’t suspect that’s changed!

@george_salmon @Jan__G Of course we can only speculate whether that’s a deliberate decision by retailers (they’d deny it because the fallout would be atrocious) or an oversight (they have teams of people who track/set/change the prices of products every day, so it would be one hell of an oversight!!)

The margins are always, always calculated to squeeze the belts of those who can least afford it, and massage the profits of those who have money to spare. And nothing demonstrates that inequality quite so starkly as tracking the prices of ‘luxury’ food vs ‘actual essentials’. 😤

And just to add:
- an upmarket ready meal range was £7.50 ten years ago, and is still £7.50 today.
- a high-end stores ‘Dine In For Two For £10’ has been £10 for as long as I can remember.
- my local supermarket had 400+ items in their value range, it’s now 91 (and counting down)
(But seeing I’ve been banging on about this for a decade now, it’s probably not going to be. Thanks for reading anyway, I appreciate it.)

Every time there’s a news bulletin on the rising cost of living, I hope that today might be the day that that some real journalism happens, and someone stops to consider those of us outside of the bubble. Maybe today might finally be that day.

But I guess when the vast majority of our media were privately educated and came from the same handful of elite universities, nobody thinks to actually check in with anyone out here in the world to see how we’re doing. (Fucking terribly, thanks for asking.)

The system by which we measure the impact of inflation is fundamentally flawed - it completely ignores the reality and the REAL price rises for people on minimum wages, zero hour contracts, food bank clients, and millions more.

These are just the ones that I know off the top of my head - there will be many many more examples! When I started writing my recipe blog ten years ago, I could feed myself and my son on £10 a week. (I’ll find the original shopping list later and price it up for today’s prices.)
Peanut butter. Was 62p, now £1.50. A price increase of 142%.

Mushrooms were 59p for 400g. They’re now 57p for 250g. A price increase of 56%. (This practise, of making products smaller while keeping them the same price, is known in the retail industry as ‘shrinkflation’ and its insidious as hell because it’s harder to immediately spot.)
A bag of small apples. Was 59p, now 89p (and the apples are even smaller!) A price increase of 51%.
Curry sauce. Was 30p, now 89p. A price increase of 196%.
Bread. Was 45p, now 58p. A price increase of 29%.
Canned spaghetti. Was 13p, now 35p. A price increase of 169%.
Baked beans: were 22p, now 32p. A 45% price increase year on year.
This time last year, the cheapest rice at the same supermarket was 45p for a kilogram bag. Today it’s £1 for 500g. That’s a 344% price increase as it hits the poorest and most vulnerable households.

This time last year, the cheapest pasta in my local supermarket (one of the Big Four), was 29p for 500g. Today it’s 70p. That’s a 141% price increase as it hits the poorest and most vulnerable households.

Woke up this morning to the radio talking about the cost of living rising a further 5%. It infuriates me the index that they use for this calculation, which grossly underestimates the real cost of inflation as it happens to people with the least. Allow me to briefly explain.

As ever, my fave trick of strong black tea along with a smudge of tomato purée works in place of red wine in most slow cooked dishes - bolognese, lasagne, ragu, risotto, bourguignon, etc. Totally heathen but the tannins in the tea give the same base note flavour as cheap wine.
Tesco do dealcoholised red wine stock pots that are good but you need a few to ramp up the flavour if you’re used to glugging half a bottle of a meaty red into your dinner.

For everyone asking: Hardys and McGuigan Zero are my favoured alcohol free white wines to cook with but to be honest I’m very cautious about it and use it rarely. It’s taken three years in (and out of) recovery to get a grasp on my drinking and I don’t want to slip back.

@DuksyG @hanness_sarah Yes. Have found Hardys and McGuigan best for AF whites - others can be terribly sweet! Tesco do red wine stock pots but I find I need to add quite a few to get the same flavour as I did…maybe says something about how much wine I used to put in my food though!!

@RubyDaly_ For red I use Tesco red wine stock pot gels, they’re alcohol free. For white I just grab whatever alcohol free there is at my local shop - usually Friexenet or Hardys or McGuigan Zero. Perfectly fine for cooking, wouldn’t personally drink it 😂

If anyone is surprised at all by the No10 lockdown parties, the obfuscation, denial, gaslighting, outright lies, the passive non-apology, the barefaced arrogance of it all, you simply haven’t been paying attention for the last eleven years.

Welcome to my world. It fucking sucks.

Paid our own travel, brought our own lunchboxes for the long night ahead.

And the people who were in a position to hear our stories and help, mugged us all off to go and get pissed instead. It’s always stayed with me, the contempt the ruling classes have for those they serve.

I asked my companion, an experienced journalist, where they went.

‘They’ve gone to the bar, someone will go and get them when it’s time to come back and vote.’

Dozens of campaigners, charities, and people in real hardship had given up their evening to try to effect change.

Seven years ago I was part of a campaign to get the rise in foodbank use in Britain debated in the Houses of Parliament. The debate was granted, I watched from the public gallery. Halfway through the harrowing testimonies many of the MPs filed out and disappeared.
@ElizabethLidd Of course he is, his mouth is moving.
@Tracey__Hanna There are. There’s still no need whatsoever for taxpayer subsidised booze in the Parliamentary estate.

So all the people saying ‘what sort of office culture lets people bring a bottle to work?’, this is the one. And if the free booze was stopped we might get a Parliament fit to serve its constituents, instead of the pissed-up arrogant sneering hooligans that currently rule us.

It’s not just the Strangers Bar, there’s the annual Conservative Party Conference champagne crates that are so infamous journalists wait to photograph their arrival, subsidised drinkies at the House of Lords, and all the other taxpayer funded piss-ups on the job. This isn’t new.

Just popping by to remind you that the Houses Of Parliament have a taxpayer-funded, subsidised bar which at any given time is rammo with working MPs getting pissed on YOUR time and money. It’s THIS culture that makes the Prime Minister think he can get away with the No10 Parties.

@AlastairAlimac5 @HolSmale With all respect, I prefer to take my specific medical advice from the qualified professionals familiar with my entire medical history. You’re entitled to your opinion on how meds work for ~you~ but blanket rubbishing them for everyone is a dangerous approach. Have a good evening

@qbnaith I found that replacing the word God with ‘Good Orderly Thinking’ or ‘Group Of (Fellow) Drunks’ helped. I don’t find any doom and gloom there to be honest, but am in a good fellowship where we mostly laugh til our stomachs hurt. Took a while to find my tribe x

- and if you are using this as the seedling for a life change because your relationship with alcohol is unmanageable and the consequences of your drinking are damaging you or people around you, your local AA/NA meeting will always have a seat available for you. 

Best of luck. X

- Allow yourself to be fully human in all its rich and bewildering catastrophes and triumphs and all the grey in between. Getting to know yourself without the false armour of alcohol or drugs is incredible. Tricky at times, but beautifully rewarding in the end.

- sometimes taking booze away means you get hit with a whole load of feelings that maybe you used to drink to gloss over or run from. Feelings are fine. They’re not facts, although they can be indicators. They can’t hurt you, although they can be intense…

- tap into something you used to enjoy doing but that maybe you ‘don’t have time for’ anymore. Quitting drink gave me MANY hours back, and I now sing, knit, draw, garden, go for big walks, see friends, hang out, watch comedy, do arts and crafts with my son, play board games, etc

- Delirium tremens, seizures, death are a risk, detox is advised. If you’re unsure, seek medical advice.

- if this is a short term challenge, sure, switch to the 0% alternatives. But most of them have led me to relapse. I didn’t drink for the taste, after all.

- if you slip up, don’t beat yourself up over it. Be like a dog - kick some leaves over that shit and move away from it. Don’t use it as an all or nothing excuse to give up on your challenge.

- if you were a habitually very heavy drinker, seek medical advice before quitting.

Hi to everyone starting #DryJanuary today!

@HolSmale I’m not an expert but my psych advised me to start on lowest dose of the slow-release medication for a week and check back in after. It’s not the dose I ended up on but it helped immensely to even be ~slightly~ more organised and less overwhelmed for a bit!

@HolSmale Other thing that helped me: therapy! There’s a matching service called Headroom or NHS Therapy For You is good. Find adhd people on here (@ADHD_Alien @blkgirllostkeys @AdultingADHD @HowtoADHD) for pennydrop moments - feeling ‘seen’ was a gamechanger for me. Am around for DMs x

@HolSmale …and by meds I mean I’m on ADHD meds, an OCD specific antidepressant, a secondary antidepressant for chronic depression, and currently on short term sleepers. If I remove any from the mix (because obstinacy, disorganisation, despair, etc) then I go seriously wonky again.

@HolSmale Yes, and I find taking my meds incredibly helpful. When I don’t take them I spiral back into very unhelpful places, usually led by the pied pipers of overwhelm and decision paralysis and emotional disregulation. Getting dose right is a bit of a journey though, there are variables

So we’ve set our alarms for 7am, because the weather app says the sun rises at 0758 here, and nothing could possibly, possibly go wrong. https://t.co/l83530GCMW

And he turned to me and said, absolutely deadpan:
‘Tomorrow morning, do you fancy getting up and seeing the sunrise?’
And I said:
‘Sounds good to me. I’ll just check my phone and see what time it says it is. Maybe we could walk out to the sea and have a spiritual experience.’

We limped/laughed/scurried back to the car, pockets full of sea pottery, stomach sore from laughing, toes numb from scampering about in the mudflats in unsuitable footwear, covered in mud and sand and seaweed.

I turned around and scampered away, back to my friend who was about a quarter of a mile back. ‘Didn’t you want to get your trainers wet?’ I asked. He pointed at the sign behind me, at the entrance to my ‘deserted beach’. https://t.co/c8VcPzno6E

And when I opened them again, there was a man in a uniform standing with what looked suspiciously like a large gun slung about his person, staring down at me with a very unimpressed look on his very hard face. This was not the spiritual apparition I was hoping for.

And I found myself on an entirely deserted stretch of beach, all by myself. Nothing and nobody as far as the eyes could see. And I stood there, and I took a deep breath, and I centred myself, and I closed my eyes. https://t.co/TmO9cTQflV
Reader, I shit myself and squelched away. You see that barrier in the distance? I ran right past it. It’s pretty cool up close. https://t.co/ElidDgqkde

After a while, we came across this. I snuck right up to it, squelching around in the mudflat, taking photographs, my face inches from the blue tarpaulin. It had just appeared in the hazy horizon. I stood and stared at it, until I noticed two men sitting in the front, staring back https://t.co/V5IZcNtdsb

On the way I started telling him about walking along this beach as a child, collecting pieces of washed up pottery. And we started collecting pieces of washed up pottery as we walked. And limped. And stumbled. Off to the sea, for our spiritual experience. https://t.co/3gvoIuQFoW

Humiliated, cross, and in pain, I turned round to grumble at my mate just in time to see him careering down on his arse behind me. We lay sprawled there giggling helplessly between bouts of swearing. And then we got up, because you see, we were going to the sea to get spiritual.

I stood at the top of this ramp, which had a big sign on saying ‘Careful, Slippery When Wet’. 

Reader, I fell down it. Flew straight from the top to the bottom on my left arse cheek, bumping against each of the footholds like a log flume in a terribly designed water chute. https://t.co/3HJDpQEArL

0730 this morning, we set off. The first thing I noticed was that it was suspiciously light outside. Neither of us said anything, just glanced at the sky and maintained a very British silence about the very obvious lack of sunrise in our plans. But we were off to get spiritual.

I looked up the sunrise time on my phone (07:59, apparently) and asked another friend if he fancied a morning trip to the sea to see if we could get ourselves some of that spiritual experience shit. We set our alarms for 7am. Tomorrow was going to be a good day.

Last night a friend of mine shared about walking out to the beach one morning to pray, and how grounded and spiritual being out there in nature made him feel. Being mildly competitive by nature, I thought, I’m gonna get me some of that. Immediately.
This is a story about my morning, and I hope it entertains you as much as it’s been entertaining me and my friends all day.
